comments.author: Noelle (@singerinkitchen)
comments.content: Wow, that looks amazing. I actually have never fresh porcini mushrooms, only dried.

comments.author: Ben G
comments.content: Yum. I just cooked two recipes from the cookbook this week. One was the tofu and onions in the sweet glaze, and the other was the polenta, mushroom, and kale casserole. My girlfriend, who doesn't normally like mushy things (polenta) or mushrooms or tofu, loved both dishes! I don't think it gets any better than that. This is one of the best cookbooks I have ever owned because the recipes are so easy yet incredibly delicious. It's been great to follow your blog for the past 2+ years and now have so much of it in a cookbook!!

comments.author: Kalyn
comments.content: I am so sad that I didn't manage to run into you at BlogHerFood!   This recipe looks amazing.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: That's always nice when someone will try something again that they haven't liked in the past, and ends up enjoying it. I'm really glad you are liking the book!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Kalyn, I'm sorry I missed you too!

comments.author: Marina@ Picnic at Marina
comments.content:
Michael, that is a treat indeed! I haven't had fresh porcini mushrooms in two years (since we moved from Seattle actually). I didn't know they sell it there, we use to pick them in the forest... :) They are not easy to find, but when you come across one it's a gourmet dream come true. When we lived in Europe, porcini mushrooms were a usual part of our dinner. Isn't it interesting how moving from one place to another affects our dinner choices, making one's peasant food gourmet for another's! :) 
Roasting juices from this recipe I would use in soup (after drinking some!).

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I really need to learn how to forage!

comments.author: Marina@ Picnic at Marina
comments.content:
:) When we move back to Seattle (next year) I'll invite you for one of those foraging "expeditions". Although, we don't forage for mushrooms by ourselves, we have some expert friends. Usually it's a hike and a foraging trip with resting on the Hood Canal (those same friends have a waterfront property there). It's a fun activity for a whole family! 
Thanks for changing commenting section, it is much easier and more user friendly, in my opinion. :) Happy Father's day, Michael!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I'd love to do that with you! And glad to hear that going back to the old way with the comments is working better for you.

comments.author: Frank @ Kraemers Culinary Blog
comments.content: I love garbanzo beans and mushrooms. What a great combination. I would imaging that the Spanish wine does magic to this dish. Since you used smoked paprika and saffron, which are popular ingredients of the Spanish cuisine. Well done!

comments.author: Vegan
comments.content: It's good that you've mentioned other mushrooms that I can use because porcini is really hard to find. I was about to try making crunchy chickpea but I decided to go for this one. I'm really excited how it would turn out. =)

comments.author: pastano
comments.content: I finally found someone that speaks my cooking language............I look forward to more good reads......Thank you.
